partial_orders.reason: These edits are part of a single documentation update within the same docstring. Edit 0 changes 'Some additional methods are' to 'An additional method is' (plural to singular), and edit 1 removes the first bullet point '_can_hold_na' from the list. This creates a direct structural dependency - the grammar change in edit 0 (plural to singular) is mechanically prompted by the removal of one item from the list in edit 1, making them part of one contiguous micro-task to maintain grammatical consistency in the documentation.

Both edits reference the exact same symbol `_can_hold_na` on ExtensionArray objects. Edit 0 changes the implementation from a property method to a class attribute set to True, while Edit 1 updates the test to assert that `_can_hold_na` is specifically True rather than just a boolean. The test change directly corresponds to the implementation change - after changing `_can_hold_na` to always be True (rather than a property that could potentially return False), the test is updated to reflect this new constraint. Both edits can be staged in either order since the test will work with both the old property implementation and the new attribute implementation.

Edit 0 removes '_can_hold_na' from a documentation list, while Edit 1 removes the '_can_hold_na' property method and replaces it with a class attribute. Both edits reference the exact same symbol '_can_hold_na' within the same class. Edit 0 updates documentation to reflect that '_can_hold_na' is no longer a property method (removing it from the list), while Edit 1 performs the actual implementation change. These edits are part of the same refactoring task - converting a property to a class attribute - and either edit naturally prompts the other as the next mechanical step.
